qas.question: Clinical hypnosis may be effective in doing what with pain associated with surgical procedures in adults and children?
How many studies in 2007 found evidence for the efficacy of hypnosis in the reduction of chronic pain?
What did the studies regarding the effectiveness of hypnosis lack?

answers.text: credible controls for placebo and/or expectation

qas.question: What is considerable more research needed to determine for different chronic pain conditions?

plausible_answers.text: evidence for the efficacy of hypnosis in the reduction of chronic pain in some conditions

qas.question: What did a 2013 review of 7 studies find?
What did meta-analyses find to be effective in controlling surgical procedures?

plausible_answers.text: the number of patients enrolled in the studies was low,

qas.question: What was found about the number of participants in 7 studies?

context: A number of meta-analyses have found <b5_0>clinical hypnosis<b5_0/> to be effective in <a0_0>controlling<a0_0/> pain associated with diagnostic and surgical procedures in both adults and children, as well as pain associated with cancer and childbirth. A 2007 review of <a1_0>13<a1_0/> studies found <b4_0>evidence for the efficacy of hypnosis in the reduction of chronic pain in some conditions<b4_0/>, though <b6_0>the number of patients enrolled in the studies was low,<b6_0/> bringing up issues of power to detect group differences, and most lacked <a2_0>credible controls for placebo and/or expectation<a2_0/>. The authors concluded that "although the findings provide support for the general applicability of hypnosis in the treatment of chronic pain, considerably more research will be needed to fully determine the <a3_0>effects of hypnosis<a3_0/> for different chronic-pain conditions."
